prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for telling their friend that her being single is due to having five kids by different fathers. 

First, the friend has been making a lot of insulting comments over two years. The author has been brushing them off, but finally responds by pointing out the friend's situation. The friend then gets upset and hangs up. The mutual friends are now taking the friend's side, saying the author was mean and had "skinny privilege," etc.

I need to consider the context. The author was constantly on the receiving end of insults and low-quality comments. The response was a truthful statement about the friend's situation, which the author believed was the root of the problem. However, the author's truth might have been a personal attack, even if factual. 

The key points are: 1) the friend was being insulting, 2) the author's response was factual but could be seen as harsh, and 3) mutual friends are now blaming the author. 

Even if the author was tired of the insults, responding with a personal truth might have crossed a line. The friend's actions (insults) don't justify the author's response, but the author's motivation was to be honest. However, in such situations, the way you respond matters. Telling someone they have multiple children by different fathers as a reason for being single is a sensitive topic and can come off as judgmental, regardless of the truth. 

Also, the author's own situation (working in the adult industry, etc.) might make them feel judged too, but that doesn't excuse a harsh response. The mutual friends' reactions suggest that the author's comment was perceived as hurtful. Even if the author's intention was to be honest, the delivery might have been unkind. 

In terms of social norms, calling out someone's personal choices, especially in a sensitive area like family and relationships, can be seen as crossing a boundary, even if it's true. So, the author might be in the wrong for not handling it more compassionately, even if the friend was being rude first. 

But then again, the friend was being insulting for two years. The author might have felt justified in finally standing up for themselves. However, the response was direct and factual, which could be seen as a low blow. 

Considering all that, the answer might lean towards A (the author is in the wrong) because even if the friend was being mean, the author's response was a personal attack that might have been unkind and unnecessary, despite being truthful.
